step.cmd: After the <context> element in your task topic, add a <steps> element.

stepxmp.pre: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <!DOCTYPE task PUBLIC "-//OASIS//DTD DITA Task//EN" "task.dtd"> <task id="task_topic"> <title></title> <taskbody> <prereq> </prereq> <context> </context> <steps> </steps> </taskbody> </task>

info.p: As with the <prereq> and <context> elements, the <taskbody> can contain only one <steps> element. In keeping with the spirit of DITA that a topic should contain a single idea, restricting you to a single <steps> element helps ensure that the topic only describes how to perform one task.

step.cmd: Inside the <steps> element, add a <step> element.

info.p: The <steps> element must contain at least one <step> element. Most DITA-aware editors automatically add a first <step> element to the <steps> element.

stepsection.p: In DITA, the content of each individual step is also highly controlled; each step has a specific set of elements, which must occur in a specific order. The action the user is to perform is contained in a <cmd> element (read as “command”), which is a required element in <step>. In most cases, <cmd> contains a single sentence, which is a direct instruction to the reader to perform some action.

step.cmd: Inside the <step> element, add a <cmd> element with the text shown here.

info.p: As a best practice, the <cmd> element should be limited to a single sentence, in active voice, that directs the user to perform an action. To provide additional information about the <cmd> element, use the <info> element (discussed in the next step).
Because <step> must contain exactly one <cmd> element, most DITA-aware editors add the <cmd> element when they add the <step> element.

step.cmd: After the <cmd> element, add an <info> element, with the text shown here.

info.p: As noted above, the <info> element provides additional information about the action dictated by the <cmd> element. You can use <info> to contain text, notes, images, tables and so on. The remaining topics in this lesson describe other, more semantically appropriate elements you can use to further document the step.

As with other elements that can contain mixed content, we strongly recommend using a

element to contain text, even if the element only contains one paragraph.
